item.title: Test-Driven Development for Scientific Programming, Part 2: Getting Started with Python
item.description: More Realistic Testing Scenarios Â¶ In the last part I outlined a brief description of TDD using the example of writing a function in Python that adds numpy arrays together. Of course in actual research, the problem you are trying to solve with code is usually a lot more complicated than just adding a few arrays. Usually you have a more complex calculation consisting of many steps, which might be performed on data in a processing pipeline.

item.title: Test-Driven Development for Scientific Programming, Part 1: Introduction
item.description: Test-driven development (TDD) is a way of writing code via creating tests, and using the tests to do design on your system. My best summary in a sentence is that TDD exists to focus the difficulty of designing programs into smaller, controllable pieces, in the form of tests. If you’re looking for a more solid definition of TDD, I invite you to watch this video of Gary Bernhardt explaining it very succinctly.

item.title: About
item.description: I am Dylan Cromer. I am a data scientist with training in cosmology, mathematics, and physics. I have experience analysing, visualizing, and modeling many different types of data. I am especially interested in the process of machine-learning model selection, testing and validation (both of software and models), and data science product QA and Product Management. I enjoy the practice of test-driven development in software, and I like to extend the logic of TDD to other domains.
